data.title: Ex-patriotism
data.meta_description: Patriotism: a love of one’s country; a belonging to country, a part of the patria, but also an ‘I’ apart, one who loves something other. To expatriate: a driving away, or a withdrawal from, one’s native land. An ambiguity in the subject here:...
data.text:
Adorno, Theodor (2005) Minima Moralia: Reflections on a Damaged Life, trans. E. F. N. Jephcott. London and New York: Verso.

Anderson, Benedict (1994) ‘Exodus,’ Critical Inquiry 20(2): 314–27.

Baucom, Ian (1999) Out of Place: Englishness, Empire, and the Locations of Identity. Princeton: Princeton University Press.

Burton, Isabel (1875) The Inner Life of Syria, Palestine, and the Holy Land. From My Private Journal (2 vols). London: Henry S. King & Co.

Burton, Isabel (2002 [1898]) The Life of Captain Sir Richard F. Burton, ed. W. H. Wilkins. Honolulu, Hawaii: University Press of the Pacific.

[Burton, Richard F.] (1865) Stone Talk (ΛΙΘΟΦΩNHMA): Being Some of the Marvellous Sayings of a Petrol Portion of Fleet Street, London, To One Doctor Polyglott, Ph.D., by Frank Baker, D.O.N. London: Robert Hardwicke.

Chesterton, G. K. (1904) ‘The Patriotic Idea,’ in England: a Nation. Being the Papers of the Patriots’ Club, ed. Lucian Oldershaw. London and Edinburgh: R. Brimley Johnson, pp. 1–43.

Kipling, Rudyard (1909) ‘An Habitation Enforced,’ in Actions and Reactions. London: Macmillan, pp. 1–51.

Kipling, Rudyard (1920) Letters of Travel (1892–1913). London: Macmillan and Co.

Kipling, Rudyard (1923) ‘The Son of his Father,’ in Land and Sea Tales for Scouts and Guides, pp. 217–51. London: Macmillan and Co.

Kipling, Rudyard (1977) Something of Myself. Harmondsworth: Penguin.

Kipling, Rudyard (1987) ‘Miss Youghal’s Sais,’ in Plain Tales from the Hills. Harmondsworth: Penguin, pp. 51–6.

Kipling, Rudyard (1996a) ‘Christmas in India,’ in The Complete Verse. London: Kyle Cathie Ltd., pp. 43–4.

Kipling, Rudyard (1996b) ‘The Return,’ in The Complete Verse. London: Kyle Cathie Ltd., pp. 393–4.

Kipling, Rudyard (1996c) The Letters of Rudyard Kipling, Volume III: 1900–10, ed. Thomas Pinney. Basingstoke: Macmillan.

Kipling, Rudyard (2002) Kim: Authoritative Text, Backgrounds, Criticism, ed. Zohreh T. Sullivan. New York and London: W. W. Norton & Company.

Knoepflmacher, U. C. (1992) ‘Female Power and Male Self-Assertion: Kipling and the Maternal,’ Children’s Literature 20: 15–35.

Lovell, Mary S. (1998) A Rage to Live: a Biography of Richard and Isabel Burton. New York and London: W. W. Norton and Co.

Matthews, Brander (1917) These Many Years: Recollections of a New Yorker. New York: Charles Scribner’s Sons.

McBratney, John (2002) Imperial Subjects, Imperial Space: Rudyard Kipling’s Fiction of the Native-Bom. Columbus: Ohio State University Press.

Naipaul, V. S. (2002) The Mimic Men: a Novel. London: Picador.

Nandy, Ashis (1983) The Intimate Enemy: Loss and Recovery of Self under Colonialism. New Delhi: Oxford University Press.

Said, Edward W. (2001) ‘Reflections on Exile,’ in Reflections on Exile and Other Literary and Cultural Essays. London: Granta Books, pp. 173–86.

Waller, J. F. (ed.) (1857) The Imperial Dictionary of Universal Biography. London: Mackenzie.
